'''John "Juke" Logan''' (September 11, 1946 – August 30, 2013) was an [[United States|American]] [[electric blues]] harmonica player, musician, singer, pianist and songwriter. He is best known for his harmonica playing on the [[theme music]] for [[television program]]s (''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]'' and ''[[Roseanne (TV series)|Roseanne]]'') and [[film]]s (''[[Crossroads (1986 film)|Crossroads]]'' and ''[[La Bamba (film)|La Bamba]]''). In addition to playing on many other musicians' work, Logan released four solo [[album]]s, and wrote songs for [[Poco]], [[John Mayall]] and [[Gary Primich]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
'''John Farrell Logan''' was born in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1441863/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=John "Juke" Logan |author=Char Ham |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=October 25, 2010}}</ref> He gained his nickname, following his constant playing of [[Little Walter]]'s track, "[[Juke (song)|J]]".<ref name="Mocombo">{{cite web |url=http://www.mocomborecords.com/juke.html |title=John "Juke" Logan |author=Michael Ventura |date= |work= |publisher=Mocomborecords.com |accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> He originally learned to play the piano, and instigated his own groups the Juke Rhythm Band, and later the Angel City Rhythm Band.<ref name="Oldies">{{cite web |url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/John-Juke-Logan.html |title=John "Juke" Logan Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Oldies.com |accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> During his time playing in Southern California, he played with several musicians who went on to work with [[John Mayall]], such as guitarists [[Rick Vito]], [[Randy Resnick]] and drummers Joe Yuele and Greg LeRoy ([[Crazy Horse (band)|Crazy Horse]]).

His early career saw Logan work as a backing musician for [[Dobie Gray]], [[Leon Russell]] and by the latter half of the 1980s, [[Dave Alvin]]. In addition, Logan's songwriting credits include John Mayall's "Fanning the Flames", Poco's "Starin' At The Sky" (co-penned with [[Timothy B. Schmit]]), plus Gary Primich's "The Sound of Money Talkin'" and "Hustler". In 1984, he worked with [[Ry Cooder]] on the [[soundtrack]] for the film, ''[[Crossroads (1986 film)|Crossroads]]''.<ref name="AMG"/> His own debut album, ''The Chill'', was released in 1995, and after moving to his own Mocombo Records,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mocomborecords.com/ |title=Custom Blues |publisher=Mocombo Records |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref><ref name="Oldies"/> followed this with ''Juke Rhythm'' (1999), the [[live album]], ''Live as It Gets'' (1999), and his final offering, ''The Truth Will Rock You'' (2005).<ref name="AMG"/>  Until 2000, Logan co-hosted a Los Angeles based weekly radio program, 'The Friday Night Blues Revue', with Ellen Bloom.<ref name="Mocombo"/> He met fellow radio DJ and musician Stephanie Riggio,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://StephanieRiggio.com |title=StephanieRiggio.com |publisher=Stephanieriggio.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> and they remained friends for decades. 

Amongst many such efforts, Logan's harmonica work has appeared on [[The Dickies]]' ''[[Second Coming (Dickies album)|Second Coming]]'' (1989),  [[Richard Marx]]'s ''[[Rush Street (album)|Rush Street]]'' (1991), the Carla Olson / Mick Taylor Band's ''Too Hot For Snakes ''(1990),<ref>Jesse Sublett, ''Never the Same Again: A Rock n' Roll Gothic ''(Berkeley: Boaz/Tenspeed 2004)</ref> Gary Primich's ''My Pleasure'' (1992) and ''Travellin' Mood'' (1994), [[Heather Myles]]'s ''[[Untamed (Heather Myles album)|Untamed]]'' (1995), [[John Mayall]]'s ''[[Spinning Coin]]'' (1995), [[John Lee Hooker]]'s ''[[Don't Look Back (John Lee Hooker album)|Don't Look Back]]'' (1997),  [[Doug MacLeod (musician)|Doug MacLeod]]'s ''Unmarked Road'' (1997), [[Adam Sandler]]'s 1997 vintage, ''[[What's Your Name?]]'', plus ''[[Stoned Immaculate: The Music of The Doors]]'' (2000), [[Sugar Ray]]'s ''[[Sugar Ray (album)|Sugar Ray]]'' (2001), ''Blue Xmas'' (various artists, 2001), Barry Goldberg's ''Stoned Again'' (2002), [["Weird Al" Yankovic]]'s 2003 album, ''[[Poodle Hat]]'', [[Etta James]]'s ''[[Blues to the Bone]]'' (2004) and [[J. J. Cale]]'s ''[[Roll On (J. J. Cale album)|Roll On]]'' plus [[Percy Sledge]]'s ''Shining Through The Rain''.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-juke-logan-mn0000808294/credits |title=John "Juke" Logan | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> Logan played the "harmonica drops" in the TV series ''[[Roseanne (TV series)|Roseanne]]'' and appeared in ''[[Home Improvement (TV series)|Home Improvement]]''.

In 2009, Logan was diagnosed with [[esophageal cancer]] and underwent successful surgery.<ref name="Club">{{cite web |url=http://clubcrawl.ning.com/profiles/blogs/meet-the-visitors-a-number-of-touring-musicians-are-joining-the-c |title=Meet the Visitors - A number of touring musicians are joining the Club Crawl® party |author=Dan Gibson |date= |work= |publisher=Clubcrawl.ning.com |accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref>

In 2010, in conjunction with [[Rick Holmstrom]] and Stephen Hodges, Logan appeared on the album, ''Twist-O-Lettz''.
<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bluesrevue.com/2011/04/rick-holmstrom-john-juke-logan-stephen-hodges-twist-o-lettz-4-8-11/# |title=Rick Holmstrom, John "Juke" Logan, Stephen Hodges: Twist-O-Lettz |author=Chip Eagle |date= |work= |publisher=Bluesrevue.com |accessdate=October 25, 2011}}</ref> In September 2011, Logan made a [[nightclub|club]] appearance in [[Tucson, Arizona]].<ref name="Club"/>

In 2011, Logan's cancer returned. In 2013, a benefit show was presented at Cafe Fais Do Do in Los Angeles, featuring [[Dave Alvin]], The Delgado Brothers, and [[Rick Holmstrom]] amongst others.

In 2013, Logan died from cancer at the home he co-owned with Stephanie Riggio in [[Joshua Tree, California]]. He was 66.<ref>{{cite web|author=September 5, 2013, 8:50 p.m. |url=http://www.latimes.com/obituaries/la-me-passings-20130906,0,179273.story |title=Obituary: Ray Grebey, John 'Juke' Logan |publisher=latimes.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-06}}</ref>
